Fig. 1 (a) CH4 and CO2 conversions after 50 h on stream and (b) WHSV-dependent reaction test of CoAl(0.50)/MA catalysts. Reaction conditions: 0.1 g, T = 800 °C, WHSV = 120,000 cm3/g·h, and CH4/CO2/C2H6/N2 (vol%) = 30/40/5/25. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Temperature-dependent reaction test on CoAl(x)/MA catalysts; (a) CH4 conversion, (b) CO2 conversion, and (c) H2/CO. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) CH4 and (b) CO2 conversion, (c) H2/CO ratio, and (d) Switching test on CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst while varying C2H6 concentration. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) H2 (m/z = 2) evolution during CH4-TPSR and (b) CO (m/z = 28) evolution during CO2-TPSR of CoAl(x)/MA catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Elemental mapping and TEM images of the reduced CoAl(x)/MA catalysts. Impact of adding C2H6 on the CO2 reforming of CH4 over Al-Incorporated Co/MgAl2O4 catalyst Jung-Hyun Park Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization ⁎ Hyeryeung Noh Writing – review & editing Methodology Data curation Hwa Sung Lee Writing – review & editing Methodology Data curation Joong Jin Han Writing – review & editing Methodology Data curation Tae-Sun Chang Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Carbon Neutral Demo-Plant Center, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, Yeosu-si, Jeollanam-do, Republic of Korea Carbon Neutral Demo-Plant Center Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology Yeosu-si Jeollanam-do Republic of Korea Carbon Neutral Demo-Plant Center, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology, Yeosu-si, Jeollanam-do, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. This study investigates the impact of incorporating aluminum (Al) as a promoter into a Co/MgAl2O4 (MA) catalyst for the CO2 reforming of CH4 with C2H6. The Co/MA catalyst exhibited the highest initial conversion of CH4 and CO2; however, both values gradually declined over the time. In contrast, all Al-promoted catalysts maintained stable conversions, and the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst demonstrated notable catalytic stability after 50 h of reaction. The weight of the Al-promoted catalyst either remained constant or increased slightly compared with the Al-unpromoted catalyst during CH4-TGA, indicating superior resistance to coking. Although the exact location of the Al species could not be determined experimentally, it can be inferred that the appropriate addition of Al to the Co/MA catalyst may partially form a CoAl2O4 phase, which facilitates CO2 activation and suppresses carbon deposition. This suggests that the Al promoter kinetically controls the rate of carbon deposition and oxidation on the Co/MA catalyst. Graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane C2H6 addition Al promoter Coking resistance Cobalt catalyst Stability Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With growing concerns about the climate crisis, there has been a surge in efforts to cut down carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from fossil fuels through various approaches [1–3]. A range of technologies and policies are being crafted to mitigate environmental impacts and encourage a transition to sustainable energy systems [4,5]. CO2 reforming of methane (CRM, Eq. 1) has been extensively studied in the recent decades because CRM can produce the synthesis gas (syngas, CO + H2) from methane and carbon dioxide [6–8]. Besides methane, other light alkanes like ethane can also undergo CO2 reforming of ethane (CRE, Eq. 2). Because ethane is the second largest component of shale gas (3 %–20 %), the discovery of global shale gas reserves has significantly increased ethane supply, providing a strong industrial foundation for its utilization and making it an attractive option [9,10]. Therefore, two reforming reactions, CRM and CRE, could be considered to produce syngas. (1) CH4 + CO2 → 2H2 + 2CO (ΔH°298K = +247 kJ/mol) (2) C2H6 + 2CO2 → 3H2 + 4CO (ΔH°298K = +428.1 kJ/mol) (3) CH4 → C + 2H2 (ΔH°298K = +74.9 kJ/mol) (4) 2CO → C + CO2 (ΔH°298K = −172.0 kJ/mol) (5) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O (ΔH°298K = −41.2 kJ/mol) (6) C2H6 → 2 C + 3 H2 (ΔH°298 K = 85.0 kJ/mol) CRM requires a high reaction temperature to overcome the highly endothermic nature of the reaction and to achieve high conversion levels [2,3,7,8]. Reforming catalysts are prone to aggregation upon exposure to high-temperature reaction conditions [3]. Additionally, competitive reactions such as methane decomposition (Eq. 3) and CO disproportionation (Eq. 4) lead to coke formation, which causes catalyst deactivation due to coke deposition during CRM [7,8]. The reverse water-gas shift (RWGS, Eq. 5) reaction can also occur simultaneously during CRM, resulting in an H2/CO ratio of less than one because the produced H2 reacts with the CO2 reactant. Moreover, coke can accumulate on the catalyst surface through ethane cracking (Eq. 6) during the CRE. Similar catalyst systems were utilized in CRM and CRE. Supported noble metal catalysts, such as Pt, Rh, Ru, and Ir, are frequently used as reforming catalysts due to their exceptional ability to break C−H bonds and their resistance to carbon buildup [3,4,7,11–13]. Nevertheless, their high expense and limited supply pose challenges for practical CRM applications. As a cost-effective alternative with good catalytic performance, Ni-based catalysts have been explored [7,14–16]. However, Ni-based catalysts are susceptible to deactivation from carbon deposition and/or reactor blockage. The carbon that accumulates on the surface of Ni particles can penetrate into the bulk phase, forming various types of graphitic carbon, including onion- and bamboo-like carbon nanotubes [17–20]. Co-based reforming catalysts have attracted interest as active metals for CRM, despite having lower reaction rate than Ni-based catalysts. The Co-based catalysts have the potential for high stability due to their greater resistance to carbon deposition compared to Ni-based catalysts [21,22]. However, this catalytic system can deactivate because of the oxidation of the active metallic cobalt, which depends on the nature of the catalyst and reaction conditions [23,24]. Support plays a crucial role in the catalytic performance of CRM [1–3]. Although γ-Al2O3 has been widely used as a support for reforming catalyst systems, its poor stability at high reaction temperatures requires alternative supports. The MgAl2O4 supported reforming catalyst have been widely applied due to its good refractoriness, low acidity, high mechanical strength, and excellent thermal shocking resistance [25–27], resulting to a low deactivation rate and a stable conversion of CH4 and CO2 [28] Research has focused on achieving stable catalytic performance by addressing the issues of coking and oxidation of active sites. Adding small amounts of noble metals like Pt or Ru to Ni or Co has been shown to effectively prevent the oxidation of metallic Co, resulting in stable catalytic performance [23,24,28–31]. In addition, non-noble metal promoters such as B, Al, Ca, La etc. can improve the catalytic performance by preventing the coke deposition and controlling between coke deposition and oxidation of deposited carbon species [28,32,33]. Bimetallic PtNi and PtCo catalysts supported on CeO2 can also applicable to CRE, with the catalyst system effectively facilitating the oxidative cleavage of C-C bonds in ethane to produce syngas [34]. Xie et al. [35] emphasized the significant impact of the support on the catalytic performance of NiPt catalysts in the CER reaction. The reaction mechanisms differ with NiPt/CeO2 following a bifunctional mechanism and NiPt/Al2O3 following a monofunctional mechanism. Liu et al. [36] also noted the positive effect of modifying Al2O3 support with Ce during the dry reforming of simulated shale gas (i.e., CH4/C2H6 mixture). Specifically, incorporating redox-active CeO2 into Ni/Al2O3 catalysts significantly enhanced carbon gasification and extended the catalyst lifetime. As previously mentioned, coke deposition is a primary challenge in designing a stable catalytic system both CRM and CRE. CRE, in particular, poses a significant risk for coke deposition due to its lower enthalpy compared to CRM [37,38]. To utilize methane and ethane, high temperature reaction conditions are necessary, and the cracking of ethane to ethylene (C2H4) and hydrogen (H2) should be considered. C2H4 can easily dehydrogenate over acid sites and quickly polymerize to form coke species [39]. Therefore, considerable efforts should be made to minimize coke deposition on the prepared catalysts. The catalytic activity of the Al-promoted Co/MgAl2O4 catalyst was enhanced during CRM by kinetically controlling coke deposition and coke removal [28]. The addition of Al species to the active Co species partly forms a cobalt spinel structure, which acts as an oxygen carrier [40]. In this study, we explored the impact of adding of Al into Co catalysts supported on MgAl2O4 for CRM when C2H6 is present. Although the CRE becomes thermodynamically favorable at lower temperatures, around 600 − 700 °C, the reforming reaction of the CH4/C2H6 mixture was carried out at a higher reaction temperature of 800 °C. Various characterization techniques were employed to elucidate the influence of the Al modifier. Several characteristic analyses and experiments on coke formation and removal were conducted to identify the reasons behind the enhanced catalytic performance of the CoAl(x)/MgAl2O4 catalyst. This study provides a guide for the design of a stable catalytic system for CH4 and C2H6 co-reforming. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts All the chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade and were utilized without further purification. The MgAl2O4 support was prepared using the precipitation method with aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Samchun, 98 %) and magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Samchun, 98 %). The standard procedure to synthesize the supports was as follows: 1 mol of Al nitrate and 2 mol of Mg nitrates were dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water, and the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 10 using a 9 % NH4OH solution (diluted with 28 % NH4OH). The resulting suspensions were aged for 3 h under vigorous stirring at 60 °C. The final products were filtered and washed twice with 3 L of deionized water. The filtered product was then dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 800 °C for 6 h in static air. A 5 wt% cobalt-based catalyst with varying Al contents Al = 0 – 1 wt%) supported on MgAl2O4 was synthesized via the impregnation method. The process utilized cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, Samchun, 97 %) and aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Samchun, 98 %) and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h under static air conditions. The catalysts were denoted CoAl(x)/MA, where x refers to the Al contents. 2.2 Catalyst Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction, N2-sorption, Raman spectroscopy, Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP), Temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD), Temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR), Temperature-programmed desorption of IPA (IPA-TPD), Temperature-programmed surface reaction of CO2 after CH4 decomposition, Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), and Thermogravimetric analysis of CH4 and CO2 were conducted to characterize the catalysts. The detailed procedure for each characterization technique is provided in the supporting information. 2.3 Activity test of CO2 reforming of CH4 with C2H6 CO2 reforming of methane (CRM) reaction with ethane (C2H6) was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor (I.D. 12 mm) at atmospheric pressure. Before the reaction, a 0.1 g sample (40–60 mesh) was pretreated at 800 °C for 1 h in a 5 % H2/N2 flow at a rate of 200 cm³ /min. The standard reactant composition consisted of 30 vol% CH4, 40 vol% CO2, and the remainder was N2, with a total flow rate of 100 cm³ /min. To assess the effect of C2H6, 5 – 10 vol% of C2H6 was introduced into the reactant stream. The reaction dependent on the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) ranged from 3000·cm3/g·h to 240,000 cm3/g·h at a temperature of 800 °C, with each experimental trial lasting 10 h. Additionally, the temperature-dependent reaction was conducted within a range of 850–750 °C, with each experimental trial lasting 3 h. The effluent gases were analyzed using on-line gas chromatography (Donam DC 7200 series) on a Carboxen 1000 column, 2 m in length and 1/8˝ in diameter, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The conversions of CH4 and CO2, the H2/CO ratio, and the degree of deactivation were calculated using the following equation: X CH 4 ( % ) = [ CH 4 ] in − [ CH 4 ] out [ CH 4 ] in × 100 X CO 2 ( % ) = [ CO 2 ] in − [ CO 2 ] in [ CO 2 ] in × 100 H 2 / CO = [ H 2 ] out [ CO ] out Degree of activity change ( % ) = X i , 50 h − X i , 1 h X i , 50 h × 100 , i = CH 4 or CO 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance in reforming reaction The impact of Al-incorporation on the catalytic properties of CoAl(x)/MA catalysts was examined in the context of CO2 reforming using a gas mixture consisting of 30 % CH4, 40 % CO2, 5 % C2H6, and 25 % N2, with a space velocity of 60,000 cm3/g·h. Prior to the catalytic tests, the calcined samples were subjected to reduction in a 5 % H2/Ar flow at 800 °C. C2H6 was dehydrogenated to form C2H4 and H2 from 700 °C and completely converted at 800 °C in a blank test (without catalyst) [41]. Thus, we conclude that C2H6 completely reacted under the reforming reaction conditions. The catalytic performance of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts was notably influenced by the Al content (Fig. S1(a, b)). The CH4 and CO2 conversions of the Al-free Co/MA catalyst exhibited a gradual decline over time; in contrast, the Al-incorporated CoAl(x)/MA catalysts demonstrated relatively stable conversion rates compared to the Al-free variant. Although the Al-incorporated CoAl(x)/MA catalysts initially displayed slightly lower conversion values, they maintained stable performance from 7 h onwards. This observation suggests that the Al-incorporated CoAl(x)/MA catalysts require a period of activation during the reaction. As shown in Fig. S1(c), the H2/CO ratios over CoAl(x)/MA catalysts are in a range of 0.79 − 0.81, which is slightly lower than the calculated value of 0.97 (CH4 + CO2 = 2 H2 + 2CO, C2H6 + 2CO2 = 3 H2 + 4CO) due to the reverse water gas shift reaction (RGWS, CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O) reaction occurring during the reaction [28,42]. Fig. 1 and Table 1 show the relationship between CH4 and CO2 conversions. The Al-free Co/MA catalyst showed a reduction in CH4 and CO2 conversions, as well as degree of increase in activity of –5.60 % and –1.89 %, respectively. However, the addition of a small amount of Al to the Co/MA catalyst kept its catalytic performance. Among the series of catalysts, the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst exhibited the largest increase in CH4 conversion after a 7 h induction period. The CoAl(0.25)/MA catalyst exhibited a nearly same values for CH4 and CO2 conversion, suggesting that the addition of 0.25 wt% Al content could kinetically be balanced for both reactants. To investigate the impact of mass transfer, catalytic performance tests dependent on WHSV were performed on the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst (Fig. 1(b)). The catalytic activity diminished as WHSV increased, attributed to the reduced contact time of the reactant on the active metal sites, which hindered the further progression of the DRM reaction. Our catalytic systems require further development for practical applications. Fig. 2 illustrates the catalytic performance tests conducted on the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, which were evaluated as a function of reaction temperature. To ensure the reliability of the results, each test was conducted three times. The conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 exhibited a decline with decreasing reaction temperature, attributable to the highly endothermic nature of the reforming reaction conditions. Despite a narrow reaction gap, the Al-promoted catalysts demonstrated greater stability compared to the Al-free Co/MA catalyst. This observation suggests that the incorporation of a small amount of Al enhances catalytic stability, even at lower reaction temperatures. To determine the effect of C2H6 concentration, CO2 reforming of CH4 and C2H6 with varying C2H6 contents was conducted on the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst ( Fig. 3). The conversion of CH4 slightly decreased for 20 h of reaction time without co-feeding of C2H6 due to the oxidation of active metals in CO2 rich atmosphere (40 % CO2). In contrast, the CH4 conversion was maintained in the presence of 5 or 10 % C2H6. Similar to the case of CH4, high and stable CO2 conversion was exhibited in the presence of 5 or 10 % C2H6, resulting from the reaction between CH4 or C2H6 and CO2, whereas the CO2 conversion under C2H6-free reaction conditions decreased gradually until the reaction time was prolonged. In the case of 10 % C2H6, the reaction was performed under a flow of 40 % CO2, indicating that the reaction was conducted under oxidant-lean conditions. Nonetheless, the catalyst maintained a stable conversion of CH4 and CO2. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the H2/CO ratios of CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst exhibited a range of 0.77 −0.81 at given reaction conditions. To investigate the switching effect of the reactants over the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst on the catalytic activity, the reforming reaction in the presence of varying C2H6 in the reactant stream was performed at 800 °C, as shown in Fig. 3(d). The conversions of CH4 and CO2 were maintained during the reaction in 30 % CH4, 40 % CO2, and 30 %N2. Upon the addition of 5 % C2H6, the CH4 conversion decreased. Still, the CO2 conversion increased as a result of further reaction between the introduced C2H6 and CO2, and both values were recovered upon stopping the cofeeding of C2H6. In the case of the co-feeding of 10 % C2H6 in the reactant stream, similar behavior was observed in the presence of 5 % C2H6, and both values were completely recovered under normal reforming conditions. This result also indicates that the addition of a small amount of Al to the Co-based catalyst can improve its catalytic activity under CH4 and C2H6 reforming conditions. Therefore, to elucidate the causes of the different reactivity of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system, several characterization methods were performed. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts The surface areas, total pore volumes and pore diameters of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts are listed in Table 2 and exhibited in Fig. S2. All the catalysts displayed type-IV hysteresis characteristic of mesoporous structures. The surface areas and pore volumes of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts ranged from 103 to 108 m²/g and 0.416–0.443 cm³ /g, respectively. The surface area decreased due to the blockage of the MA support's pores. These values slightly decreased with increasing Al content up to 0.5, but increased in the CoAl(1.00)/MA catalyst compared to the Co/MA catalyst because it might be formed alumina on the catalyst surface. The pore volumes showed similar values across the CoAl(x)/MA series. The pore diameter, derived from the desorption branch, was consistently around 15.6 nm for the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system. The CoAl(x)/MA catalyst exhibited bimodal pores of 13.4 and 15.6 nm, with the 13.4 nm pore increasing as Al content rose. The active metallic Co dispersion of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts was observed to be in the range of 4.08–4.86 % (Table 2). Among the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system, the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst exhibited the most considerable dispersion of 4.86 %. Additionally, the compositions of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, as determined by ICP analysis, were in good agreement with the theoretical values (Table 2). This result indicates that the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts were well prepared. The XRD patterns of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the XRD reflections corresponding to the lattice planes at (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) confirmed the spinel structure of MgAl2O4 (JCPDS No. #04–008–1061). The XRD patterns of cobalt oxide and metallic cobalt were not observed for any of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts because the diffractions of cobalt-related peaks and MgAl2O4 are not well resolved, which can be attributed to their similar 2θ values. Additionally, to further investigate the structure of the cobalt oxide, the Raman analysis was carried out, as shown in Fig. 4(b). It is known that CoAl2O4 spinel or Co3O4, belonging to the space group Fd3 m (Oh7), should exhibit five Raman-active bands (A1 g + Eg + 3 F2 g). Raman spectrum of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts shows strong Raman bands at 197, 479, 525, 618, and 687 cm−1 [43,44]. The band at 687 cm−1 can be assigned to A1 g species in Oh7 spectroscopic symmetry, whereas 618, 525, and 197 cm−1 peaks are assigned to three F2 g symmetry species, and the bands at 479 cm−1 are due to Eg symmetry. Despite the challenges in distinguishing the Raman bands of Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 due to their similarity, it is observed that all Raman-active bands, particularly the A1 g species in Oh7, exhibit an increase with higher Al content. Raman analysis suggested that the Co3O4 phase was mainly formed on the catalyst surface, coexisting with partially form of CoAl2O4. To investigate the reduction properties of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, H2-TPR experiments were performed, as shown in Fig. 4(c). Typically, the reduction of Co3O4 in a catalyst exhibits several characteristic peaks during the H2-TPR. A prominent peak at approximately 200 − 500°C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, potentially with a weak interaction between cobalt and the support. The high-temperature peak at 800 °C is associated with the reduction of CoO to metallic cobalt (Co) or the formation of spinel phases of Co3O4 [45]. In our catalyst system, all catalysts exhibited three typical reduction peaks, classified as follows: 200 − 450 °C (peak I), 550 − 700 °C (peak II, with a shoulder peak), and 700 − 950 °C (peak III). Peak I could be assigned to the reduction of Co3O to CoO, and peak II could be associated with the reduction of Co species that strongly interact with MgAl2O4 [46,47]. Peak III could be related to the reduction in the formation of cobalt-containing spinel phases [48]. The reduction temperature was shifted to a lower value by the addition of Al to the Co/MA catalyst, and the CoAl(0.25)/MA catalyst exhibited the lowest temperature. This result indicates that the addition of a small amount of Al to the Co/MA catalyst can more readily reduce Co species on the MgAl2O4 support. The peak intensity of peak II increased with increasing Al content, and the intensity of peak III decreased compared to that of the Co/MA catalyst, indicating that the increase in Co species strongly interacted with the support and reduced the spinel phases. The H2-TPR results suggest that the Al promoter can positively affect the reduction properties of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system. The acid–base properties of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts were characterized using IPA-TPD ( Fig. 5). In this technique, propylene and acetone are produced through dehydration to acetone (CH₃COCH₃) and dehydrogenation to propylene (C3H6) on the acid and base/redox sites, respectively. Thus, the ⋅C3H5 (m/z = 41) and ⋅CH3CO (m/z = 43) fragments were used as indicators of the acidic and basic/redox properties of the catalysts [49]. For all the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, two desorption peaks related to propylene were observed: a desorption peak (peak I) centered at 139 °C and a broad peak (peak II) in the range of 180 − 280 °C (Fig. 5(a)). The temperature of peak I was nearly the same for all CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, and the temperature of peak II shifted to higher temperatures with increasing Al content, with the CoAl(1.00)/MA catalyst exhibiting the highest desorption temperature of 246 °C. In addition, the peak intensities of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts were similar to and lower than those of the Co/MA catalyst. The desorption behavior of propylene suggests that the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts had relatively fewer and weaker acidic sites, and the acidic strength of the catalysts weakened with increasing Al content compared to the Co/MA catalyst. The acetone fragment also showed a distinguishable peak centered at 167 °C (peak I) and a shoulder peak (peak II) in the high-temperature region for all CoAl(x)/MA catalysts (Fig. 5(b)). Both peak temperatures exhibited similar values, regardless of the presence of Al in the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system. With increasing Al content, the intensity of peak I decreased, and that of peak II increased. The desorption behavior of acetone suggests that the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts have relatively more basic/redox sites than the Co/MA catalyst, and the basic/redox strength of the catalysts decreased in the presence of Al. To examine the carbon deposition rate from CH4 decomposition, TGA was performed on the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts under 5 % CH4/He flows ( Fig. 6(a)). Prior to analysis, all CoAl(x)/MA catalysts were reduced at 800 °C using a 10 % H2/He flow; the change in sample weight was attributed to the two-step reduction of Co3O4. As shown in Fig. 6(a), the weight of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts increased significantly when introducing CH4/He to the catalyst bed, resulting from carbon deposition due to the dissociation of CH4. The weight of the Co/MA catalyst rose notably until a reaction time of 2 min, followed by a more gradual increase. While all CoAl(x)/MA catalysts exhibited a marked initial weight increase, the Al-promoted CoAl(x)/MA catalysts displayed varying weight behaviors during the CH4-TGA. The weight of the CoAl(0.25)/MA catalyst remained stable until the reaction time of 45 min, while the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst showed stability until a reaction time of 25 min before gradually increasing. Although the weight of the CoAl(1.00)/MA catalyst increased continuously, the rate of this increase was less than that of the Co/MA catalyst. The carbon deposition rate of the Al-unpromoted Co/MA catalyst was faster than that of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, indicating that the Co/MA catalyst facilitates CH4 dissociation more effectively than the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system. In other words, the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts showed better coking resistance during CH4 dissociation than the Co/MA catalyst, which can be attributed to the partial formation of Co spinel phase To further investigate the carbon elimination rate of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, TGA was conducted under a CO2/He flow following exposure to a CH4/He atmosphere at 800 °C. CH4 decomposes into various CHx species on the active metal sites, with the final form of Cads (carbon adsorbed on the metal surface) remaining on the metallic sites [50,51] during CH4/He treatment. All catalysts exhibited an initial spike, which might be due to the partial oxidation of the Co species. The weight of the Co/MA catalyst decreased gradually during TGA under a CO2/He flow. This weight reduction was linked to the elimination of carbon species resulting from oxidation by the surface oxygen species originating from CO2 dissociation. The Co/MA catalyst exhibited the greatest weight reduction compared to the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst, as more carbon species were deposited on the Co/MA catalyst during CH4-TGA (Fig. 6(a)). Nevertheless, the carbon elimination rate of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst surpasses that of the Co/MA catalyst, indicating a shorter elimination time for the carbon species. However, the carbon elimination rate of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst is higher than that of the Co/MA catalyst, suggesting a shorter elimination time for the carbon species. The observed times during the analysis decreased in the following order: CoAl(0.25)/MA < CoAl(0.50)/MA < CoAl(1.00)/MA < Co/MA. The CoAl(0.25)/MA catalyst exhibited the highest coking resistance and facilitated the oxidation of deposited carbon by oxygen species on its surface. To understand the mechanism of coke resistance, we conducted a series of temperature-programmed surface reactions. It is widely recognized that in the CRM reaction, CH4 cracking and CO disproportionation are the primary sources of coke formation, while CO2 contributes to carbon elimination by reacting with surface O(s) generated from CO2 dissociation [52]. Consequently, a CH4-temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) experiment followed by a CO2-TPSR was conducted to evaluate the CH4 activation and CO2-assisted coke removal properties of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts. Fig. 7(a) presents the H2 evolution (CH4 = C(s) + 2 H2) profiles of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts. H2 evolution commenced in all CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, displaying several H2 evolution peaks; the initial peak temperature ranged from approximately 300–470 °C, and the second peak began at 550 °C, peaking at around 690–730 °C. As the Al content increased, the temperature required for CH4 decomposition decreased. The H2 evolution temperature of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst was lower than that of the Co/MA catalyst, and the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst system exhibited a similar peak temperature. CO2-TPSR was performed on the spent catalyst after the CH4-TPSR to assess the elimination of coke deposited with CO2. The CO signal was detected during CO2 activation (C(s) + CO2 = 2CO), as shown in Fig. 7(b). The starting temperature of CO evolution for all the catalysts was 520 °C and extended to 800 °C. The CO evolution temperature decreased with the addition of Al, reaching a maximum at 616.8 °C for Co/MA, 583.6 °C for CoAl(0.25)/MA, 590.8 °C for CoAl(0.5)/MA, and 601.9 °C for CoAl(1.0)/MA catalysts. Al incorporation facilitates the oxidation of the deposited carbon species by the O species derived from CO2 dissociation. This result aligns well with the CO2-TGA results. Fig. 8 illustrates the elemental mapping of Co in conjunction with the TEM images of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts. The impregnated Al species were not readily discernible when dispersed on the surface or at the interface of MA, a phenomenon attributed to the Mg-Al oxide support. The Co particle sizes for the Co/MA and CoAl(0.25)/MA catalysts were approximately 7–10 nm in diameter. With an increase in the Al content, the Co particle sizes decreased and appeared to be relatively well-dispersed compared to those of catalysts with no or low Al content, as evidenced by elemental mapping. The existence of a CoAl2O4-related phase was also confirmed by the determination of lattice spacings of 0.320 and 0.460 nm for the (002) and (111) planes, respectively [53]. Therefore, although the precise reason for this observation cannot be confirmed, the added Al species may interact with the Co species, facilitating their dispersion on the catalyst surface. In addition, irregular shapes of Co-related particles were observed in the Al-promoted catalysts with Al contents above 0.50. The irregular shape and aggregation of the Co species can be attributed to the simple impregnation method, which cannot control the size of metal particles. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts To assess the extent of carbon deposition during the reaction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on the spent CoAl(x)/MA catalysts ( Fig. 9). All catalysts demonstrated several weight changes within the temperature range of 50 – 800 °C. The weight loss observed below 400 °C was attributed to the desorption of adsorbed water molecules or the oxidation of amorphous carbon species. For the Co/MA catalyst, no significant weight change was detected above 400 °C, suggesting that filamentous-type carbon was not deposited on the catalyst surface due to exposure to CO2-rich reaction conditions. However, the possibility of carbon deposition on the Co/MA catalyst cannot be entirely excluded due to potential analytical errors or the possibility of carbon deposition on certain parts of the catalysts. In contrast, for the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts, the weight loss observed between approximately 450 and 650 °C was associated with the oxidation of carbon deposited on the catalysts, which increased with higher Al content. The TGA profile of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst in a 5 % CO2/He atmosphere is presented in Fig. 9(b). The catalyst's weight gradually decreased within the temperature range of 500–700 °C, with the degree of weight reduction being lower than that observed in air. This finding suggests that the deposited carbon species could be oxidized in the presence of CO2, which acted as a mild oxidant. Typically, the weight loss observed at approximately 400 °C is associated with highly reactive amorphous carbon, while the higher temperature of > 500 °C corresponds to less-active carbon species (filamentous carbon) resulting from further dehydrogenation and polymerization of amorphous carbon [50,51]. The filamentous carbon did not result in complete deactivation of the reforming catalyst, which could cause plugging and breakage of the reactor system. XRD analysis was conducted to assess the structural change following the reaction, as depicted in Fig. S3. The CoAl(x)/MA catalysts did not demonstrate any significant structural alterations post-reaction. However, a carbon-related peak was detected at 26° in the XRD analysis, with its intensity increasing in correlation with the Al content. Furthermore, Figure S4 presents TEM images of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts after 50 h of reaction in the presence of 5 % C2H6. The Al-promoted CoAl(x)/MA catalysts displayed typical filamentous carbon species, while metallic Co was observed either in the middle or at the tips of the carbon filaments. In contrast, the Co/MA catalyst did not exhibit filamentous-type carbon. These findings for the used catalysts were consistent with the TGA results (Fig. 9). 4 Discussion The carbon species were mainly deposited by C2H6 cracking during the reforming reaction of CH4 and C2H6. C2H6 decomposes into C2H4, which plays a key role in coking [34]. To study the coking resistance of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts for the C2H4 species, TGA was performed on the Co/MA and CoAl(0.25)/MA catalysts after exposure to 6 % C2H4/N2 for a specific period ( Fig. 10(a)). The weight loss observed for both catalysts below 400 °C is related to carbon deposits on the surface, which then stabilize. The Co/MA catalyst exhibited a larger weight loss than the CoAl(0.25)/MA catalyst, indicating that more coke was formed on the Co/MA catalyst. The amount of carbon deposits related to the exposure time is shown in Fig. 10(b) and Table 3. For the Co/MA catalyst increased gradually with increasing exposure to C2H4. The weight of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst remained nearly constant. Among the Al-promoted catalysts, CoAl(0.25)/MA had the lowest weight, which increased gradually over time. Clearly, the Al-promoted CoAl(x)/MA catalysts showed a higher coking resistance than the Co/MA catalyst. The Co-Al oxide species on the catalyst surface or at the interface between the active Co species and the support might prevent carbon buildup through C2H4 cracking. Although it is difficult to distinguish the Co-Al oxide species on the surface or interface because of the small amount of Al added, the presence of Al species significantly contributes to the coking resistance. To better understand the coking resistance, TPO analysis was performed after exposure to 5 % C3H6/He, which represents a higher hydrocarbon species. A ·CO2 signal (m/z = 44) was observed during TPO, indicating the reaction between the carbon formed from C3H6 cracking and the oxygen in the gas phase. The peak temperature of CO2 had a similar value of 643 °C, suggesting that crystalline carbon species were formed on the catalyst surface. The peak area calculated by integrating the peak in the 400 – 700 °C temperature range increased in the following order: CoAl(0.25)/MA < CoAl(0.50)/MA < CoAl(1.00)/MA < Co/MA, which is in good agreement with the TGA results (Fig. 9). Even with exposure to higher hydrocarbons, the Al-promoted catalysts showed more coking resistance than the Co/MA catalyst. The TGA and TPO results suggest that the addition of an appropriate amount of Al to the Co/MA catalyst can significantly improve the coking resistance and provide a good idea for catalyst design. While the Al species cannot activate either CH4 or CO2 during the reaction, the incorporation of an appropriate quantity of Al significantly enhanced the stability of the Co-based catalysts. The primary cause of deactivation in Ni- and Co-based reforming catalysts is coke deposition [54,55]. In this study, although the TGA results did not indicate a notable change in weight of the Co/MA catalyst attributable to carbon oxidation, a gradual decline in the conversion of CH4 and CO2 was observed. Consequently, it was inferred that another factor contributed to the deactivation of the Co/MA catalyst, specifically the oxidation of the Co species. Conversely, the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst exhibited a significant weight reduction during TGA, which appeared reasonable given the catalytic activity of the CoAl(x)/MA catalyst. The incorporation of Al into the Co/MA catalyst system can partially form a CoAl2O4 phase, which may increase with higher Al content; 0.82 wt% for CoAl(0.25)/MA, 1.64 wt% for CoAl(0.50)/MA, and 3.28 wt% for CoAl(1.00)/MA catalysts. These values were calculated based on the assumption that added Al species completely reacted with Co species. This could have resulted in a decrease in the amount of metallic Co in the catalyst. The reduced initial catalytic activity of the CoAl(x)/MA catalysts may lead to a diminished active Co phase. Although we were unable to determine whether the partially formed CoAl2O4 phase is located near the active Co or at the interface between the Co and MA supports, our catalyst system notably enhanced catalytic stability during CRM with C2H6. It can be concluded that the partially formed CoAl2O4 phase may play a significant role in the CRM with C2H6. The introduction of Al species to the Co/MA catalyst can modulate the acid-base properties of the catalysts due to the acidic nature of the Al species. The acidic sites and strength of the catalysts diminished with the addition of Al species, and the basic properties of the catalyst were also affected by the Al promoter, as shown in Fig. 5. Controlled acid-base properties can influence the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface. CO2 functions as an oxygen donor on the catalyst surface during the reforming reaction via CO2 dissociation. Therefore, CO2, with its mildly acidic properties, can more readily adsorb on the basic sites of the catalysts. In the case of the Co/MA catalyst, CO2 is more strongly adsorbed on the MA support than on the Al-promoted catalysts, facilitating the dissociation of CO2 into CO(s) and O(s) species. The strongly adsorbed O(s) species effectively removed the deposited carbon species during the reaction. As depicted in Fig. 9, no distinct weight decrease was observed for the Co/MA catalyst; however, CH4 and CO2 conversions declined. The remaining O(s) species may have further oxidized the active Co species, leading to a reduction in the catalytic activity of the Co/MA catalyst due to the decreased number of accessible active sites. In contrast, an appropriate amount of Al promoter effectively prevents further oxidation of the active Co species because the partly formed CoAl2O4 during calcination acts as an oxygen carrier towards the deposited carbon species [40]. Although the precise location of the Al promoter and the formation of the CoAl2O4 phase could not be identified experimentally, the Al promoter can play a crucial role in the reforming system as a cheap and abundant promoter. In this regard, we are studying the development of a new strategy for identifying the locations of Al and CoAl2O4 formations, which will be reported in the future. 5 Conclusions We present a CoAl(x)/MA catalytic system with varying aluminum (Al) contents for CO2 reforming of methane (CRM) in the presence of ethane (C2H6). The incorporation of Al into the Co/MA catalyst system significantly enhanced the catalytic stability of CRM with C2H6. Notably, the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic performance and stability with 50 h on stream. A comprehensive analysis utilizing CO2-TGA and CO2-TPSR analyses confirmed the facilitation of CO2 dissociation, with its concentration being adjustable through the modulation of Al loading. The CH4-TGA results indicated an improvement in coking resistance for the Al-promoted Co/MA catalysts compared to the unpromoted one. The CoAl(x)/MA catalysts exhibited enhanced coking resistance for ethylene (C2H4), the primary product of C2H6 cracking. While the exact location of the Al species could not be determined experimentally, incorporating Al species into the Co-based catalytic system resulted in improved catalytic stability. We propose that the integration of an abundant and cost-effective Al component represents a promising strategy for designing catalysts with high coking resistance in reforming reactions. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the impact of incorporating aluminum (Al) as a promoter into a Co/MgAl2O4 (MA) catalyst for the CO2 reforming of CH4 with C2H6. The Co/MA catalyst exhibited the highest initial conversion of CH4 and CO2; however, both values gradually declined over the time. In contrast, all Al-promoted catalysts maintained stable conversions, and the CoAl(0.50)/MA catalyst demonstrated notable catalytic stability after 50 h of reaction. The weight of the Al-promoted catalyst either remained constant or increased slightly compared with the Al-unpromoted catalyst during CH4-TGA, indicating superior resistance to coking. Although the exact location of the Al species could not be determined experimentally, it can be inferred that the appropriate addition of Al to the Co/MA catalyst may partially form a CoAl2O4 phase, which facilitates CO2 activation and suppresses carbon deposition. This suggests that the Al promoter kinetically controls the rate of carbon deposition and oxidation on the Co/MA catalyst.
